abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment discusses
            the negative environmental impacts that result from
            constructing five roads, and upgrading other roads, for the
            Road Maintenance and Development Project for Nepal.
            Mitigation measures include limiting the area of disturbance
            and land take, sequencing construction activities to save
            the double handling of materials, installing all major
            retaining and drainage works in the initial year of
            construction (prior to the monsoon), and progressively
            revegetating the completed batters. The pegging of the road
            formation areas and ancillary sites enables works to be
            confined, which reduces the area of disturbance and the loss
            of productive resources. Vegetation clearance will be
            controlled to limit the loss of production resources, damage
            to surrounding features, and ground disturbance and the
            associated erosion hazard. Retaining walls will enable
            backfilling of the wall and reduce the likelihood of fill
            sidecasting below the road formation area. Topsoil will be
            stripped and stockpiled, and then respread on batters.
            Excess fill will be disposed of at low impact sites. Noise
            will be controlled by restricting work and blasting hours,
            and prohibiting the use of air horns. Finally, compensation
            will be paid for the loss of land, buildings, and crops or
            other natural resources; community assets and resources will
            be repaired or replaced; allowances will be paid and
            rehabilitation measures extended to displaced households.
